April 13, 1980: Fiction
THE BOURNE IDENTITY, by Robert Ludlum. (Richard Marek, $12.95.) The
melodramatic adventures of an amnesiac trying to find out who he really is.
PRINCESS DAISY, by Judith Krantz. (Crown, $12.95.) The fight for survival in the
world of glitter, from St. Petersburg to Big Sur.
THE DEVIL'S ALTERNATIVE, by Frederick Forsyth. (Viking, $12.95.) Countdown
to global doom in 1982.
SMILEY'S PEOPLE, by John le Carr√©. (Knopf, $10.95.) The great British spy has
a final confrontation with his Russian counterpart.
PORTRAITS, by Cynthia Freeman. (Arbor House, $9.95.) The Sansonitskys of "A
World Full of Strangers" reach the 1920's and 30's.
WHO'S ON FIRST, by William F. Buckley Jr. (Doubleday, $9.95.) Blackford Oakes
plays his part in the race with the Russians to get a satellite into orbit.
THE BLEEDING HEART, by Marilyn French. (Summit Books, $12.95.) An
American feminist's romance in England.
SOPHIE'S CHOICE, by William Styron. (Random House, $12.95.) The nature of
evil explored through the story of two doomed lovers.
TRIPLE, by Ken Follett. (Arbor House, $10.95.) Power play between intelligence
agents in the Middle East.
CREEK MARY'S BLOOD, by Dee Brown. (Holt, Rinehart & Winston, $12.95.) Four
generations of American Indian family life on the Great Plains.
HUNGRY AS THE SEA, by Wilbur Smith. (Doubleday, $9.95.) Heroism and dirty
business on the high seas.
MEMORIES OF ANOTHER DAY, by Harold Robbins. (Simon & Schuster, $10.95.)
Saga of the American labor movement.
THE ESTABLISHMENT, by Howard Fast. (Houghton Mifflin, $11.95.) The
Lavettes of "The Immigrants" and "Second Generation" survive and prosper in
post-World War II America.
THE TOP OF THE HILL, by Irwin Shaw. (Delacorte, $8.95.) A jaded New Yorker
courts danger in New England.
JAILBIRD, by Kurt Vonnegut. (Delacorte/Seymour Lawrence, $9.95.) From World
War II to Watergate: one man's fumbling career.
April 13, 1980
Non-Fiction
FREE TO CHOOSE, by Milton Friedman and Rose Friedman. (Harcourt Brace
Jovanovich, $9.95.) The Nobel laureate economist and his wife discuss the
relationship of government and the economy: tie-in to the current PBS series.
DONAHUE, by Phil Donahue. (Simon & Schuster, $9.95.) The host of the popular
television talk show tells his life story.
ALL YOU NEED TO KNOW ABOUT THE IRS, by Paul N. Strassels with Robert
Wool. (Random House, $10.95.) A former tax law specialist at the IRS offers
advice and insight.
THE BRETHREN, by Bob Woodward and Scott Armstrong. (Simon & Schuster,
$13.95.) Inside the Supreme Court.
ANATOMY OF AN ILLNESS, by Norman Cousins. (Norton, $9.95.) A patient's
account of his successful fight against a serious disease.
THE THIRD WAVE, by Alvin Toffler. (Morrow, $14.95.) The changes our society is
about to undergo: a pop prognosticator's analysis.
THE BOOK OF LISTS #2, by Irving Wallace, David Wallechinsky, Amy Wallace
and Sylvia Wallace. (Morrow, $12.95) More facts that entertain.
THE PRITIKIN PROGRAM, by Nathan Pritikin with Patrick M. McGrady, Jr.
(Grosset & Dunlap, $12.95.) A prescription for health and long life.
HOW YOU CAN BECOME FINANCIALLY INDEPENDENT BY INVESTING IN
REAL ESTATE, by Albert J. Lowry. (Simon & Schuster, $10.95.) How-to.
ORDEAL, by Linda Lovelace and Mike McGrady. (Lyle Stuart, $10.00.) The former
porn movie actress recounts her travails.
AUNT ERMA'S COPE BOOK, by Erma Bombeck. (McGraw-Hill, $8.95.) How to
get from Monday to Friday... in 12 days.
THEY CALL ME ASSASSIN, by Jack Tatum with Bill Kushner. (Everest House,
$9.95.) The N.F.L. defensive back says that in pro football violence is the name of
the game.
JAMES HERRIOT'S YORKSHIRE, by James Herriot. (St. Martin's Press, $15.) An
illustrated tour of the veterinarian's homeland.
ON A CLEAR DAY, YOU CAN SEE GENERAL MOTORS, by J. Patrick Wright.
(Wright Enterprises, Grosse Pointe, Mich., $12.95.) John Z. De Lorean, a former
top executive, gives his view of the automotive giant.
